thread.title: Yemeni eater owner serves tour group fighting Trump with palates
thread.title_full: Yemeni eater owner serves tour group fighting Trump with palates - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Yemeni eater owner serves tour group fighting Trump with palates
text:
The owner of a Yemeni restaurant in Brooklyn grew emotional Saturday as he welcomed a tour group focused on food from the nations included under President Trump’s travel ban.
“It brings tears to my eyes to see all these people show us so much support,” said Abdul Erahim, 30, as he carried two plates of lamb shanks to a table of hungry tourers inside his Yemen Cafe.
“We've really seen an outpouring of support from the neighborhood here," he added, noting that business has actually picked up after the ban was implemented.
Damascus Bread & Pastry Shop owners Gus Matli (l.) and Tony Sadek (r.) satisfied the sweet tooths of the tour groups with Syrian baked goods. (Kevin C Downs/For New York Daily News) "People have been coming in non-stop.”
The “Middle Eats Food Tour" had about 50 people munching on delicacies like sweet pistachio-laced baklava and savory slow-roasted lamb stew as they walked from Yemeni cafes to Syrian bakeries in Brooklyn’s Cobble Hill neighborhood.
Dear Ferst (c.), holds a tray of baklava as tour group members flood the small bakery. (Kevin C Downs/For New York Daily News) “There’s no better way to get a feel for someone's culture than to share a meal with them,” said organizer Scott Wiener, who banded together with three others to launch a series of tours under the name Breaking Bread NYC.
The tour took a sweet turn when it stopped at Damascus Bread and Pastry, where small squares of syrupy baklava were served to the participants.
Erahim said business at the Yemeni restaurant has picked up since the ban. (Kevin C Downs/For New York Daily News) “I'm so happy that we're here to show everyone our great food,” said clerk Gus Matli as waves of people flooded the small bakery on Atlantic Ave.
Several participants said they were delighted to take such a delicious stand against Trump’s immigration policies.
“The travel ban is absurd,” said Crown Heights web designer Emily Panzer, 30, as she tore through a freshly-baked piece of malog bread.
“To sit here and literally break bread with them will help bring everyone together.”
